metadata.title: Antibacterial consumption in the context of COVID-19 in Pakistan: an analysis of national Short Title: Antibacterial consumption COVID-19 Pakistan Methods: We used IQVIA pharmaceutical sales volume data to analyze antibiotic consumption for

body_text.text: Analysis: Data analysis was performed at the ATC level 3 (therapeutic groups) using two measures 89 of AbC: total consumption and consumption pattern. AbC was analysed as Defined Daily Doses 90 (DDD) per 1000 population per day, or DID (14) . For this comparative analysis, we used the 91 estimated population for 2019 of 216565318 and factored in a 2.1% growth to give the population 92 for 2020 as 221113190 (15).

One standard unit was 97 a tablet, capsule, vial or ampoule. For oral suspensions or syrups meant for use in children, the 98 standard unit was 5 ml (17). For example, the unit pack-size for an oral liquid substance presented 99 as a 60 ml bottle was 60/5, or 12 standard units. With drops, the standard unit was adopted as 1. 123 . Within "others" the rise was driven by 139 increase in the consumption of sulfamethoxazole-trimethoprim. coupled with COVID-19 related decrease in outpatient attendance in hospitals (18, 19) .
body_text.section: (which was not certified by peer review)

body_text.text: In contrast, the rise in the consumption of macrolides in March, and, in April 2020, of "others" 151 antibiotics, may have been a result of stock-piling by medicine outlets or clients of azithromycin, 152 following its social-media promotion, alongside chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine, as a 153 preventive or treatment for COVID-19. While "others" also rose, this increase was smaller, being 154 about three orders of magnitude lower. FIGREF0.text: for the treatment of tuberculosis. The extracted dataset contained 77 antibiotics available as 4648 81 products (tablets, capsules, injections/infusions, suspensions/oral powders for suspension and oral 82 drops of different dosage form strengths).

FIGREF1.text: IQVIA dataset was reclassified into current (2019) ATC codes, and based on a preliminary 84 analysis of sale volumes, recategorized into six therapeutic groups: (I) J01A, tetracyclines, (II) 85 J01C, beta-lactams, penicillins (III) J01D, other beta-lactams, (IV) J01F, macrolides, (V) J01M, 86 quinolones, and (VI) "others", consisting of eight sub-groups or individual antibiotics not already 87 classified.

FIGREF3.text: Thus, a pediatric dropper of 10 ml volume had a unit pack-size of 10. Monthly DIDs were then 101 aggregated by therapeutic group.102Total AbC per year was calculated using the formula above by substituting two terms, namely the 103 'monthly sale amount' with the 'total monthly sales for all four months' and the 'days in the month'104 with a time period of 121 for 2020 and 120 for 2019. To analyse temporal changes, we used a 105 "year-on-year" change (%) metric comparing the "yearly" DID for the first four months of 2020 106 to 2019. 107 AbC pattern was described in terms of proportions (%) of total AbC by therapeutic group for each 108 month. To analyse differences in consumption pattern we used a month-on-month change (%) Table 1. FIGREF5.text: 2020 consumption was lower for antibiotics for systemic use (ATC J01) during the study 133 period of January-April, except for macrolides which showed a rise for February and March 134 of 2020, and "others" with an increase in April 2020. 135 Within the macrolidesazithromycin, clarithromycin, clindamycin, erythromycin, lincomycin 136 and roxithromycinazithromycin was the most commonly-consumed. In March 2020, 137 azithromycin contributed 50% to macrolide sale volume with a related consumption of 1.70 DID,

FIGREF6.text: One of the characteristics of the present outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic is the 141 general medical uncertainty due to the fact that both the agent (SARS-CoV2) and the disease were 142 completely unknown six months before this study was conducted. Within this context of 143 uncertainty, lack of sound evidence and an unprecedented amount of circulating information, to 144 analyse the consumption of a few antibiotics involved in this information overload is of interest 145 because of the impact of inappropriate consumption on the global AMR threat. 146 This analysis revealed a "year-on-year" drop in total AbC in the first four months of 2020. This 147 may have due to an economic crisis with currency devaluation and price increases that started in 148 2018 and supply chain disruptions from these and border closures with China and India in 2019,149

FIGREF7.text: Within the context of COVID-19, three classes of antibacterials are of interest: macrolides,156    quinolones, and aminoglycosides.
